description: From 23 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to colleges and facilities for carrying out college study programmes. Special provisions relate to: The deadline of proofing mandatory additional tests; the holding of exams; the discontinuation of specific activities; the retry of an academic year; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses. Exams that have been taken or registered in the summer term 2020 and prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 23 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions to universities and teacher's colleges. Special provisions relate to: The division of the academic year; entry into force of curricula; admission periods; the notification of the continuation of studies; the taking of supplementary tests in art studies; the introductory and orientation phases of studies; the leave of absence; the deadline of study expirations at universities; courses and exams; the taking of exams by electronic means; the submission of bachelor, diploma and master theses, diploma and master theses in art studies and dissertations (also in art studies); periods of transition for studies and courses. Exams that have been taken or registered in the summer term 2020 and prior to the announcement of this policy are in accordance with these rules if without any grave flaws. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021. The counting of terms according to §§ 6 and 9 of this policy may also be valid following its termination if related to studies registered in the summer term 2020 and still eligible.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 26 May 2020, the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Research in Austria applies special provisions for the determination of deadlines and criteria in aptitude, acceptance and selection procedures at universities, teacher's colleges, facilities for carrying out college study programmes, colleges and private universities in the context of the 2020/2021 academic year. Special provisions relate to: The consistent setting of schedules and deadlines; the holding of aptitude, acceptance and selection procedures at universities and teacher's colleges; the acceptance procedure with respect to human and dental medicine; the acceptance procedure at colleges. Additionally, in cases of necessary physical presence at the aforementioned instances, safety measures are to be followed. The policy is slated to end on 30 September 2021.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
At Austrian press conference on August 17th, Education Minister Heinz Faßmann presented the plan for reopening schools. The minister “wants” schools and childcare facilities to resume regular instruction in the fall, but has outlined measures to reduce the spread of the virus.
Schools will be coordinated with the Health Ministry’s “Corona Ampel” (traffic light) that is planned to go live this fall. Some measures:
- Sick children should stay home.
- Windows in classrooms will be opened for at least five minutes every 20 minutes, even once temperatures grow colder during fall and winter.
- Masks must be worn upon entering and exiting school buildings, but are not required inside classrooms.
- Teachers will be provided with FFP2 masks and receive a flu shot.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On September 3, 2020, an Austrian school regulation created a traffic light system for conditions of school operation and closure, based on infection rates in the school and households of pupils. 

The green phase is the least restrictive, with measures such as holding classes outside wherever possible. 

In the yellow phase, additional conditions apply. All people on school premises must wear face coverings in hallways and common rooms. Lessons for wind instruments must be held outdoors, and singing lessons must take place either outdoors or indoors with face coverings. 

The orange phase includes aforementioned rules, plus additional rules. School events are not allowed. School management may schedule classes to begin at different times to avoid congregations of people. No singing or wind instrument lessons may take place indoors. Sports lessons must take place outside where possible, or indoors with social distancing. The number of hours in compulsory subjects may not exceed ten. Temporary offsite lessons must be provided temporarily for grades 9 and above. 

During the red phase, temporary offsite lessons must be provided for all grades. 

Different end dates apply to different provisions of the regulation.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Physical classroom hours or meeting times reduced (e.g. classes only meet in the morning; classes meet every other day),School event cancelled or postponed,Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Education,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 25, 2021, Austria enacted a school regulation that requires proof of vaccination and testing for school teachers, administrative staff, and students. Teachers and administrative staff must either provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19, or proof of a negative coronavirus test at least once per week. Voluntary testing must be available for students as often as is necessary to demonstrate a low epidemiological risk level every day. The policy applies only to the academic year of 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021. UPDATE: The original policy required teachers and administrative staff to show proof of vaccination. This has been changed to proof of a second vaccination dose at least 22 days and no more than 270 days prior.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
institution_status: Primary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test,Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation concerning air quality. For activities involving singing, playing woodwind instruments, and physical activities like sports, additional ventilation is required, as determined by an individual school's hygiene plan. These activities should take place outside whenever possible. When outdoor activity is not possible, students must remain at least two meters apart when playing music, and one meter apart when playing sports, unless like sport required physical contact. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation requiring a three-week safety phase at the beginning of the academic year 2021/2022. During this phase, pupils, teachers, and administrative staff must (1) wear face coverings in hallways and common areas (not classrooms); (2) provide proof of negative coronavirus tests at least once per week, or as often as necessary to demonstrate low epidemiological risk. Teachers and administrative staff are exempt from the testing requirement if they provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced an order requiring schools to allow delayed or repeated examinations. Up to two late exams for the summer semester of the academic year 2019/2020, or the entire academic year 2020/2021, may be taken or repeated up to November 30, 2021. Students with more than two failed or foregone exams from the year 2020/2021 may advance to the next school level, unless they do not pass the requisite number of exams by November 30, 2021.

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation requiring a three-week safety phase at the beginning of the academic year 2021/2022. During this phase, pupils, teachers, and administrative staff must (1) wear face coverings in hallways and common areas (not classrooms); (2) provide proof of negative coronavirus tests at least once per week, or as often as necessary to demonstrate low epidemiological risk. Teachers and administrative staff are exempt from the testing requirement if they provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022. UPDATE: The original policy required face coverings, and it has been updated to require FFP2 respirators for all adults and students above the 9th grade.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On the 27th of January, Austria set up a priorisation scheme for COVID 19 vaccines. The policy decreed that people older than 80 and those with disabilities and their assistants were to be vaccinated first. From February 1st, people older than 65, people that otherwise formed part of a risk group, people in 24 hour care as well as their caretakers and people who live in a household with pregnant women, could also be vaccinated. In the case that there is sufficient serum and it cannot be used to vaccinate those more at risk in a timely manner, all people with health insurance can be vaccinated as well. Vaccination is provided by the nationstate.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: An Austrian health ministry order created a priority list for COVID-19 vaccinations administered by primary care doctors that went into effect on January 28, 2021, and was set to expire on September 30, 2021. The highest priority group, whose eligibility began on January 28, 2021, includes (1) persons over the age of 80, and (2) persons with disabilities and their carers. The second priority group, whose eligibility began on February 1, 2021, includes (1) persons at least 65 years in age, (2) persons in specified high-risk groups, (3) persons in 24-hour care, their carers, and people in their households, and (4) persons living in the same household as a pregnant person.

update_level_var: [compliance] of policy relaxing ; timing of policy strengthening
description: From 14 April 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons who want to enter Austria from bordering countries are obligated to carry a medical certificate in German, English, Italian or French which shows that molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 were negative. The medical certificate cannot be older than four days upon entry. If failing to do so, persons can be denied entry. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on April 30. UPDATE: From 1 May 2020, the applicability of this policy to entries by land is made explicit. Exceptions for entering Austria are extended to those that are "necessarily to be enabled" to enter Austria if directly applicable to provisions of constitutional and Union law. Seasonal workers in the agricultural and silvicultural sectors as well as nursing and health personnel are allowed to enter Austria by rail or bus if there are no halts in between. An obligatory quarantine for 14 days also applies to these individuals. The municipalities of Vomp-Hinterriss, Mittelberg and Jungholz are now exempted. Those in need of serious medical assistance in Austria can, in addition to having an Austrian citizenship or being covered by a medical or private insurance in Austria, be exempted if they can submit a treatment assurance by an Austrian hospital related to exceptional medical reasons. The policy now also does not explicitly apply to public transport passengers if, in the case of travelling through foreign territory, there are no halts in between. Entry restrictions are extended to May 31.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Austrian Airlines will take to the air again on June 15. For the beginning, direct flights to ten destinations within or close to Europe will resume. All tickets can be rebooked flexibly and higher hygiene standards (e.g. mandatory masks for travelers, higher frequency of disinfection etc.) apply throughout the check-in process and flight. The following destinations can be reached from Vienna in the first week of the restart (June 15-21):
Amsterdam, Athens, Basel, Berlin, Brussels, Bucharest, Dubrovnik, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt, Geneva, Hamburg, Copenhagen, Larnaka, London, Munich, Paris, Prishtina, Sarajevo, Skopje, Sofia, Stockholm, Stuttgart, Tel Aviv, Thessaloniki, Tirana, Varna und Zurich.

In the second week (June 22-28), Belgrade, Graz, Innsbruck, Kiyv, Kosice, Milan, Nice, Prague, Split und Warsaw are to follow.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
From June 16, Austria permits again travels to and from 31 European countries. Travelers do not need to go into quarantine or present a coronavirus test result when traveling to Austria from these countries. Different rules may still apply for entering some of these countries coming from Austria. The 31 countries are:

Belgium, Bulgaria, Denmark and the Färöer islands, Germany, Estonia, Finland, France, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy (a travel warning is still in force for the province of Lombardy), Croatia, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Romania, Switzerland, Cyprus and the micro states Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican City.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Health Minister Rudolf Anschober (Greens) announced that starting this Thursday, July 16, planes coming from 10 countries will no longer be permitted to land in Austria due to rising coronavirus infection rates there. Including these new restrictions, Austria bans direct flight traffic with 18 countries in total. These countries are:
Belarus; China; United Kingdom; Iran; Portugal; Russia; Sweden; Ukraine; Bulgaria; Romania; Moldava; Egypt; Serbia; Bosnia & Herzegovina; North Macedonia; Albania; Kosovo; Montenegro

description: In Austria, Anyone entering the country from one of 32 states or territories defined as having an unstable or risky COVID-19 situation has to self-quarantine at home for 14 days. If the result is negative, there is no need for home quarantine. Alternatively, travelers can also present a negative test result not older than four days upon crossing the border. The countries and territories classified as risky are: Albania, Bangladesh, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brazil, Bulgaria, Chile, Egypt, Ecuador, India, Indonesia, Iran, Kosovo, Mexico, Moldova, Montenegro, Nigeria, Northern Macedonia, Pakistan, Peru, Philippines, Portugal, Romania, Russian Federation, Sweden, Senegal, Serbia, South Africa, Turkey, Ukraine, United States and Hubei Province (China).
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
The Austrian government issued a travel warning for the Spanish mainland, which will enter into force on Monday, August 10, 2020.
The warning is currently not valid for the Spanish islands, i.e. the Balearic islands and the Canaries.That means that travelers coming back from the Spanish mainland to Austria will have to show a negative COVID-19 test result, otherwise they need to enter a 10-day quarantine.

description:
The Austrian government announced that from January 15th 2021, people entering Austria from a defined high-risk area are obligated to submit key information, in order to facilitate contact tracing. The pre-travel clearance online form serves this purpose and needs to be submitted electronically before entering the country. In exceptional cases, e.g. if someone does not have the technical means to fill out the document online, the form can also be filled out and used in printed form. 
Some exceptions exist for certain groups (e.g. regular commuters).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
From 02/10/2021, commuters entering Austria from countries with high infection rates must carry a negative PCR or antigen test result that is not older than seven days. If no test result is available, the test must be carried out within 24 hours.

Registration through the Pre-Travel Clearance Form is now also mandatory for commuters. A new registration is required every time there is a change, but at the latest after seven days.

description:
Austria, May 1, 2021
Austria will permit those who are:
1. Humanitarian forces,
2. Persons who, for the purpose of exercising a compulsory judicial or
officially imposed duty, such as carrying out charges too
Court hearings, entry,
3. Foreigners, if they have a photo ID in accordance with Section 5 of the Official Seat Act,
Federal Law Gazette I No. 54/2021,
4. An accompanying person as part of the entry for medical reasons 
5. People who visit an international institution
6. Austrian citizens, EU / EEA citizens or Swiss citizens, or Persons with a place of residence or habitual abode in Austria.

In addition, a ten-day quarantine must be commenced immediately. 
The quarantine is deemed to have ended when a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 is not carried out before the fifth day after entry and the test result is negative. 

Travelers must pay for the tests themselves.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description:
Austria, May 12, 2021.
You may enter the country if have vaccination card.
Equivalent to COVID-19 if the following conditions are met:
1. from the 22nd day after the first vaccination, although this was not more than three months ago
may, or
2. Second vaccination, whereby the first vaccination must not be more than nine months ago, or
3. Vaccination from the 22nd day after vaccination for vaccines that only have one vaccination
is provided, whereby this must not be more than nine months ago, or
4. Vaccination, provided a positive molecular biological test at least 21 days before vaccination proof of neutralizing antibodies was available for SARS-CoV-2 or before the vaccination, the vaccination must not be more than nine months ago.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Police

description: An Austria order dated May 12, 2021 creates a special external border rule for Germany. If someone crosses into Austria from Germany, and they can credibly demonstrated that they have stayed exclusively within Germany or Austria within the last ten days, then they must carry proof of COVID-19 vaccination, recovery, negative test result, or a medical certificate and present it for possible inspection. Absent one of these things, they must present the result of a molecular biological test for SARS-CoV-2 or an antigen test within 24 hours of entry at a migration control point. The traveler is responsible for the test's cost.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting January 24th, 2022, Angola, Botswana, Denmark, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mosambique, Namibia, the Netherlands, Norway, Zambia, Zimbabwe, South Africa and the United Kingdom are no longer classified as countries with a variant of concern.
Following this, and in accordance with the "2G+" regime, only travelers with a proof of recovery or vaccination and an additional PCR negative test result can enter Austria. Those who vaccinated with a booster shot are exempt from the additional PCR testing requirement.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

Following this, and in accordance with the "2G+" regime, only travelers with a proof of recovery or vaccination and an additional PCR negative test result can enter Austria. Those who vaccinated with a booster shot are exempt from the additional PCR testing requirement.

description: From February 28 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that air carriers are required [...] to immediately report passengers who have been in an area for which a travel warning related to the occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 has been pronounced in the last 14 days before the start of the trip, and who have arrived at an airport in Austria. If passengers from countries for which a travel warning related to SARS-CoV-2 has been issued are confirmed to be infected with SARS-CoV-2, air carriers are required to immediately provide the entire passenger list. The policy is slated to end on June 30.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Austrian government has established a “strategic reserve” of masks and protective gear as a reaction to the scramble for equipment at the beginning of the pandemic.
In cooperation with the Red Cross, the government purchased 2.6 million respiratory masks, 44.4 million surgical masks, 1.7 million examination gloves, 430,000 protective overalls, 37,000 protective goggles, 150,000 disposable aprons and 19,500 pulse oximeters with finger clips.
In addition, 9,000 oxygen masks, 50,000 CoV test kits and 991,000 CoV rapid tests were stored in five facilities of the Austrian Bundesheer (Federal Army).
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On February 19th, Austria prepared in a number of ways for shortages of medicine and oxygen. Issuers of medical products are, under certain conditions and given certain informations, allowed to request the issuance of products extending the expiration date. This will be tested and, if succesfull approved by the state. Furthermore, if oxygen shortages arise in connection with COVID, firms that are not officially registered for medical oxygen related business, but are approved under pharmaceutical law can bottle oxygen. Also, oxygen can be bottled in various safe containers that are not normally permitted for medical purposes.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
In Austria from August 19, Defense Minister Klaudia Tanner announced that she will send 800 additional soldiers to Austrian borders to support health officials in conducting health check-ups.
Additionally, Chancellor Sebastian Kurz is ordering 500 police officers to the borders. UPDATE: UPDATE: To support health officials in conducting health checks at the borders, the government will send 60 additional soldiers to the Styrian-Slovenian border and 60 more to the border crossings located in Carinthia.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 16 March 2020, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering public spaces is prohibited. Exceptions exist. The policy is slated to end on March 22. UPDATE: From 20 March 2020, if protection measures for lowering the risk of infection are implemented, they may replace minimum distance provisions. Funerals within closest family circles are now exempted from lockdown restrictions. Exceptions for entering work places are now valid only if professional activities cannot be carried out outside of the work place. However, it is made explicit that professional activities are preferably to be carried out outside of the work place if possible and mutually agreed upon by employees and employers. Lockdown restrictions are extended to April 13.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Effective December 17th, 2021, Austria introduced a so-called "Holiday Ninja Pass" for young people of school age from Austria and abroad who have not been (fully) vaccinated or do not have proof of past infection to use alternative 2-G proof in Austria. 
The Ninja Pass, by means of docmenting a series of test results, is equivalent to 2-G proof for 7 days for teenagers, from age 12 and born on or after 1 September 2006, if 
a. there is proof of a valid negative test result from day 1 to day 5,
b. at least 2 of the tests taken are molecular biological tests for SARS-CoV-2 (PCR tests) and, 
c. all official test certificates are recorded in the Holiday Ninja Pass in analogue or digital form.
The Holiday Ninja Pass regulations are analogous to those of the Corona Test Pass (Ninja Pass) at Austrian schools, according to which the period of validity for antigen tests is 48 hours and for PCR tests 72 hours, and is valid for the winter season 2021/22.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_text: The policy in question provides alternative means for non-fully vaccinated and recovered school-aged children in Austria to achieve 2-G status.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People of a certain age (please note age range in the text entry)
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Effective January 3rd 2022, a booster shot is required for those who were vaccinated with a Johnson & Johnson vaccine to count as 'fully vaccinated' in the Austrian national vaccine app ("Green Pass" or "grüner Pass" in German).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: This policy redefines the "fully vaccinated" status. From January 3rd 2022 onward, two instead of one Janssen COVID-19 vaccine shots (first shot + booster shot) are required to count as fully vaccinated.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective February 1st, 2022, Austria becomes the first country to enforce a mandatory COVID-19 vaccine mandate for residents aged 18 or older, with exemptions for pregnant women and people who cannot receive the vaccine on medical grounds. The law takes effect on February 1 but police checks won't be carried out until March 15. Unvaccinated people then face a penalty of around €600 and up to €3,600. In total, those not complying with the mandate can be fined up to four times a year. A fine will be dropped if the recipient gets vaccinated within two weeks of receiving the penalty notice.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: This policy enforces a national COVID-19 vaccination mandate.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective February 1st, 2022, Austria becomes the first country to enforce a mandatory coronavirus vaccination policy. This mandate will apply to residents 18 years or older, with exemptions for pregnant women and people who cannot receive the vaccine on medical grounds. The law takes effect on February 1 but police checks won't be carried out until March 15. Unvaccinated people then face a penalty of around €600 and up to €3,600. In total, those not complying with the mandate can be fined up to four times a year. A fine will be dropped if the recipient gets vaccinated within two weeks of receiving the penalty notice.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description:
The Austrian Foreign Ministry issued a travel warning for the countries of the Western Balkans due to rising coronavirus cases in the region.
Concretely, the ministry advises not to travel to Serbia, Montenegro, Bosnia & Herzegovina, North Macedonia, Albania and Kosovo.
Travelers coming from these countries to Austria need to self-quarantine for 14 days or show a negative COVID-19 test result.

description:
Travelers entering Austria from any of the following countries (see below) need to self-quarantine for 14 days at home or otherwise show a negative COVID-19 test result.

People living in Austria are advised not to travel currently to the following countries (in parentheses, number of new coronavirus infections in the last 14 days per 100,000 inhabitants): Bosnia & Herzegovina (6.2) Montenegro (8.4) Serbia (5.2) Montenegro (8.5) North Macedonia (9.3) Albania (3.4) Bulgaria (2.8) Romania (2.6) Moldova (8.5) Ukraine (2.7) Turkey (2.1)

description:
The federal states of Lower Austria and Upper Austria shortened the quarantine period for COVID-19 suspected cases to 10 days from previously 14 days.
The change follows a recommendation from the Ministry of Health.
The quarantine can only be ended if there are still no symptoms after 10 days; for people who tested positive for the coronavirus in the past or who show symptoms, a negative test result is obligatory.

description:
From 19th of December, the Federal Ministry of Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that persons entering the country from a defined risk area are required to quarantine for 10 days upon arrival. After 5 days of quarantine at the earliest, you may take a PCR or antigen COVID test to shorten the quarantine. Moreover, it is possible to end the quarantine if the person decides to leave the country.

The only countries considered as non-risk areas are Australia, Finland, Ireland, Iceland, Japan, New Zealand, Norway, South Korea, Uruguay, and the Vatican, which are exempted from the policy.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Carinthia are closed, announced March 12 by the regional government. This policy effectively extends over the whole rest of the 2020 skiing season. After that, it automatically becomes obsolete, as it only relates to skiing in winter 2020. The end date is thus implied, though not specified. UPDATE: It was announced that the skiing season would be terminated early for 2020. No explicit end date of the policy was mentioned, but it was implied that there would be no more skiing possible in Carinthia for the rest of the 2020 winter, with the policy effectively becoming obsolete after that.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Styria are closed, announced March 12 by the regional government. UPDATE: There was no clear end date announced for the policy. However, it was implicitly clear that the policy would become obsolete after the winter, as it related only to the skiing season, which was terminated early for the year.

description:
In Austria, from March 17, 2020, all hotels in Tyrol are closed. announced March 12 by the regional government. UPDATE: From May 28th, all acommodation establishments are allowed to open again on a national level under restrictions. UPDATE: There was no end date announced inititally for the closure of accomodation establishments. The Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and 
Consumer Protection announced that from May 28th, accomodation establishments were allowed to open again.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: In Austria, from April 4, i is forbidden to enter hotels and other accommodation facilities, such as inns, guesthouses, private room rentals. This applies for recreational and leisure purposes, but not for business purposes. UPDATE: UPDATE: In Austria, from April 4, non-essential businesses include now also hotels. It is forbidden to enter hotels and other accommodation facilities, such as inns, guesthouses, private room rentals. This applies for recreational and leisure purposes, but not for business purposes. valid until April 24. UPDATE: UPDATE: In Austria, from April 4, non-essential businesses include now also hotels. It is forbidden to enter hotels and other accommodation facilities, such as inns, guesthouses, private room rentals. This applies for recreational and leisure purposes, but not for business purposes. valid until April 24.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From April 6th 2020, mask wearing is required in all retail businesses in Austria. Moreover, keeping a one meter distance to other customers is required.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Austria, from March 16, 2020, all ski lifts in Salzburg are closed, announced March 12 by the regional governments. The skiing season is terminated early for the year. UPDATE: All lifts and cableways are to stay closed until  April 30th. UPDATE: Initially, no clear end date for the closing of lifts was specified, except that the skiing season was terminated early for the year. On April 10th, Salzburg announced that all lifts were to stay closed until April 30th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
From March 17, 2020, Austria announced the closing of restaurants and bars.

From April 21, 2020, Austria announced that:
From May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
From May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask
 UPDATE: The original policy had restaurant and bars close from 3PM on; later - policy closed restaurants and bars entirely. 

The new policy indicates that from:
May 1: all shops and stores can reopen, including hair & beauty salons;
May 15: restaurants, bars and other businesses in the hospitality industry can reopen (until 23:00 in the night), for staff it’s mandatory to wear mask

From 1 May 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited for visitors. The policy is slated to end on June 30.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 29 May 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds is allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 for outdoor sports grounds) of the source document are met. Entering the visitor areas of leisure facilities is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. Entering the premises of the sex trade industry remains to be prohibited. The policy is slated to end on June 30.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

Entering sports grounds is allowed if conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 (§ 1, section 1 and § 8, sections 2 to 5 for outdoor sports grounds) of the source document are met. Entering the visitor areas of leisure facilities is now allowed if the conditions according to § 2, section 1, numbers 1 to 3 (§ 1, section 1 for outdoor visitor areas) of the source document are met. Entering the premises of the sex trade industry remains to be prohibited. The policy is slated to end on June 30.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
From May 29th, hotels and other accomodation facilities can reopen in Austria. Nevertheless, certain control measures have to be insured: 
- Ensure a minimum distance of 1 meter (Place information by means of displays, signs, stands, floor markings or other aids in the entrance areas and at the reception of the accommodation company and etc).
- Design the catering area (Observe guidelines for catering establishments for general information)
- Adapt additional offers (fitness areas and wellness areas, according to their requirements)
- Place recommendations for behavior that are clearly visible to the guest
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 15 June 2020, the Federal Ministry for Social Affairs, Health, Care and Consumer Protection in Austria enacts that entering the premises of all modes of operation in the catering industry is allowed if certain conditions are met (see [type_business_var]). Conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of May 29. For some facilities, following these rules is not explicitly mandatory (see exceptions section). The policy is slated to end on August 31.

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00). UPDATE: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). description:
The Austrian ski school union has released new corona guidelines for the upcoming winter season.
-Ski and snowboard instructors must be tested for the coronavirus on a regular basis. The union has requested for testing costs to be paid for by the Ministry of Agriculture, Regions, and Tourism.
-Groups are capped at ten individuals, including the instructor.
-All students must register their contact information.
-In case an individual shows corona symptoms, he or she must be separated from the group.
-Masks are required whenever the minimum distance cannot be kept.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 3 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed and with the addition of COVID-19 prevention concept provisions), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as has been enacted on May 1, yet, slightly narrowed and relaxed in general), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). description:
From May 29th, hotels and other accomodation facilities can reopen in Austria. Nevertheless, certain control measures have to be insured: 
- Ensure a minimum distance of 1 meter (Place information by means of displays, signs, stands, floor markings or other aids in the entrance areas and at the reception of the accommodation company and etc).
- Design the catering area (Observe guidelines for catering establishments for general information)
- Adapt additional offers (fitness areas and wellness areas, according to their requirements)
- Place recommendations for behavior that are clearly visible to the guest.

From 3rd of November, this policy is no longer valid (hotels must close) UPDATE: From 3rd of November, this policy is no longer valid
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From 11 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if social distancing, face covering or other infection protection measures are followed (see [type_business_var]). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions, prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions, prohibited. For business premises, conditions have changed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 3. The policy is slated to end on November 30 and replaced by the previous set of policies on December 1.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 17 November 2020, entering the costumer areas of defined trade or leisure facilities or in the context of defined service provisions is, with exceptions, prohibited. Besides that, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met. Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are narrowed when compared to the regulatory situation of November 11), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 6.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From 7 December 2020, entering the costumer areas of business premises of any sort (or outdoor markets) is allowed if certain conditions are met (which are the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, significantly extended). Entering sports grounds for carrying out sports activities is, with exceptions (which are mostly the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly relaxed and differentiated), prohibited. Entering leisure facilities for entertaining, amusing or recreational purposes is, with exceptions (which are almost the same as had been enacted on November 3, yet, slightly differentiated), prohibited. The policy is slated to end on December 23.

description: In Austria, from 7th of December, retail shops (and services, like friseur) can reopen again. The trade will open again from December 7th, the shops may stay open until 7 p.m. at the latest. It is mandatory to wear mouth and nose protection. For customer areas there is a limit of 10 m 2 per customer.
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Police

description: From December 26th, all non-essential shops must close in Austria. Shops are only allowed to offer Click & Collect services. Moreover, businesses with close body contact (e.g. hairdressers) must close.
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description: From December 26th, all non-essential shops must close in Austria. Shops are only allowed to offer Click & Collect services. Moreover, businesses with close body contact (e.g. hairdressers) must close. UPDATE: The original policy was set to last until January 17th, it has been extended to February 7th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Police

description:
From February 8th, all retail businesses are allowed to open under certain conditions:
-Shops are allowed to open between 06:00-19:00
-each customer needs 20m2 space
-medical masks (FFP2) are required to be worn by customers and staff

This policy applies to all businesses, except for catering, which remains closed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From February 8th, all businesses with close body contact (e.g. hairdressers) are allowed to open again, under certain conditions:

-Customers are required to show a negative COVID-19 test result, which needs to be from the past 48 hours
-Customers are required to wear a medical FFP2 mask 
-each customer needs 10m2 space
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Personal Grooming Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers,Health Certificate

description: Austria requires body - related service providers, essentially health and care workers, to provide a negative antigen or molecular biology Covid 19 test no older than 48 hours for external work. The policy takes effect as part of a broader announcement on February 18th and is set to end on February 27th.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: From February 19th, the requirement for proof of 2G will no longer apply in restaurants, cafes, bars or hotels. This will be replaced with a 3G requirement, meaning that people without 2G can show a recent negative Covid test to enter these venues. To enter restaurants, cafes and bars, PCR tests will only be valid for 48 hours after the time of the test, but in all other areas (eg. for entering workplaces), PCR tests will remain valid for 72 hours (note that Vienna has a blanket rule of 48-hour validity).
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Negative COVID-19 Test,Proof of COVID-19 Vaccination,3G: Must be either (i) vaccinated, (ii) have a valid COVID-19 negative test within a certain time frame, or (iii) recovered from COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
With election day approaching fast in Vienna, safety measures are being put in place for voting in the Vienna election on October 11, 2020.
Voters can visit one of 1,494 voting stations between 7:00 and 15:00 on October 11.
Facemasks must be worn inside the voting stations and voters are requested to bring their own pen with them to fill out the ballot.
Postal ballots (also called absentee ballots, Wahlkarte) can already be mailed in or submitted. Voters who have not received one in the mail can also pick it up at the Magistrate for your district.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
Since March, Austrian national policy set restrictions and has forbidden visits senior houses, from May 4 this policy is no longer valid (visits from May 4 are available, but under strict conditions to protect the people living there).

Some of the restricions:
-Coordination of visits by the facility, an appointment in advance is required.
-Set limited hours of visit by the facility.
-Limitation of the number of visitors.
-In the first step, the visits to the facilities should only take place individually (one visitor per resident).

description: The administration of Vienna has issued new regulations (35. Verordnung) for visits in hospitals, nursing and care homes, starting from the the 29.05.2020. Visits are allowed again but only with mandatory masks and one visitor per 10 m2 in the patient rooms. Patients are only allowed to have one visitor per day, two visitors are only allowed in exceptions (such as childbirth, dementia, citical life phases). Visits of a person with potential symptoms of Covid 19 are still prohibited. Visits of children are only allowed in exceptions.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The administration of Vienna has issued new regulations (35. Verordnung) for visits in hospitals, nursing and care homes, starting from the the 29.05.2020. Visits are allowed again but only with mandatory masks and one visitor per 10 m2 in the patient rooms. Patients are only allowed to have one visitor per day, two visitors are only allowed in exceptions (such as childbirth, dementia, citical life phases). Visits of a person with potential symptoms of Covid 19 are still prohibited. Visits of children are only allowed in exceptions. UPDATE: From November 3rd, Austria announced a nationwide lockdown, which includes new regulations on visiting health facilities. Thus, this policy is not valid anymore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The administration of Lower Austria has issues new regulations for hospital visits since the 01.06.2020. The general regulations for all visitors of patients within hospitals, care homes and other health spaces are the mandatory use of a mask, desinfection of hands, making an appointment beforehand, a minimum 1 meter distance between individuals and a maximum amount of visitors per room. However, individual hospital also have specific additional regulations, which vary in the allowed length of the visit (20 min to 45 min), specific visitation periods and testing when entering the main entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The administration of Lower Austria has issues new regulations for hospital visits since the 01.06.2020. The general regulations for all visitors of patients within hospitals, care homes and other health spaces are the mandatory use of a mask, desinfection of hands, making an appointment beforehand, a minimum 1 meter distance between individuals and a maximum amount of visitors per room. However, individual hospital also have specific additional regulations, which vary in the allowed length of the visit (20 min to 45 min), specific visitation periods and testing when entering the main entrance. UPDATE: From November 3rd, Austria announced a nationwide lockdown, which includes new regulations on visiting health facilities. Hence, this policy is not valid anymore.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The administration of Salzburg issued new regulations for hospital visits on the 04.06.2020. Since then patients are allowed to have one visit per day by one person. More visitors are only allowed in exceptional situations, such as childbrith or crisis situations. General hygiene regulations are mandatory mask use, one meter distance and disinfecting hands.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: The administration of Salzburg issued new regulations for hospital visits on the 04.06.2020. Since then patients are allowed to have one visit per day by one person. description: In Tyrol, hospital visit regulations have been allowed again since the 04.06.2020 but only under strict regulations. Patients, who have been staying at a hospital for more than a week, are allowed to have only one visitor per day for a maximum of 30 minutes. For people accompanying a patient into the hospital, Corona tests via smear testing are mandatory. Furthermore, individual hospitals have issues some additional regulations for their specific spaces.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Upper Austria (OÖ) has announced new hospital visit regulations according to the 4x1 Rule, starting from the 05.06.2020. Under this rule, a patient is allowed one visitor per day for one hour, most likely during the afternoon. Furthermore, hospitalized children are allowed to be visited by both parents, but not silmultaneously. Ambulance regulations stay the same and require 1,5 m distance betewen patients.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: In Tyrol from March 13 Restrictions of visitors also for Tyrol's residential and nursing homes, recommended to install an access control system in the entrance area. Furthermore, all visitors who are granted access to the facilities should be recorded with their name, address and telephone number. UPDATE: The complete ban of hospital visits in Tyrol has been ended on the 05.06.2020 and been replaced by regulated hospital visits under new restrictions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
In Austria, starting September 1, Austrian Airlines is limiting the exceptions to the mask requirement.
Previously, passengers with a medical letter were exempt from wearing a mask when flying. Now, the medical letter must be written on an AUA-Formblatt, and passengers must provide a negative corona test result.
Since May, passengers have been required to wear masks upon entering the respective terminal until they arrive at their destination.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: In Austria from September 21, In restaurants, a maximum of 10 people can sit on one table. Masks have to be worn everywhere when not sitting. Consuming drinks and food is only allowed when seated.

description:
Starting June 15th, 2020, the Austrian government requires staff in restaurants, who cannot keep a distance of 1 meter from the customer, to continue to wear masks or something to fully cover nose and mouth.

This policy ended on November 3, after new lockdown was implemented and restaurants had to close (only take away service)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Austria, the original policy limited the working time and number of people of restaurants and bars, as well as mandatory masks wearing requirements for customers and personnel existed (from May 15th). Starting on June 15th, people will be able to sit on a restaurant table with more than 4 people (also from different households), masks will be mandatory only for personnel and restaurants and bars can stay opened until 1:00 am in the morning (before until 23:00).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The administration of Vienna has issued new regulations (35. Verordnung) for visits in hospitals, nursing and care homes, starting from the the 29.05.2020. Visits are allowed again but only with mandatory masks and one visitor per 10 m2 in the patient rooms. Patients are only allowed to have one visitor per day, two visitors are only allowed in exceptions (such as childbirth, dementia, citical life phases). Visits of a person with potential symptoms of Covid 19 are still prohibited. Visits of children are only allowed in exceptions. UPDATE: Due to the rapid increase of COVID-19 cases, this policy does not apply anymore and new regulations exist for hospitals and nursing homes.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description:
From February 8th, all retail businesses are allowed to open under certain conditions:
-Shops are allowed to open between 06:00-19:00
-each customer needs 20m2 space

This policy applies to all businesses, except for catering, which remains closed.

From February 8th, all businesses with close body contact (e.g. hairdressers) are allowed to open again, under certain conditions:

-Customers are required to wear a medical FFP2 mask 
-each customer needs 10m2 space

description:
On September 3, 2020, an Austrian school regulation created a traffic light system for conditions of school operation and closure, based on infection rates in the school and households of pupils. 

The green phase is the least restrictive, with measures such as holding classes outside wherever possible. 

In the yellow phase, additional conditions apply. All people on school premises must wear face coverings in hallways and common rooms. Lessons for wind instruments must be held outdoors, and singing lessons must take place either outdoors or indoors with face coverings. 

The orange phase includes aforementioned rules, plus additional rules. School events are not allowed. School management may schedule classes to begin at different times to avoid congregations of people. No singing or wind instrument lessons may take place indoors. Sports lessons must take place outside where possible, or indoors with social distancing. The number of hours in compulsory subjects may not exceed ten. Temporary offsite lessons must be provided temporarily for grades 9 and above. 

During the red phase, temporary offsite lessons must be provided for all grades. 

Different end dates apply to different provisions of the regulation.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Education,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation concerning air quality. For activities involving singing, playing woodwind instruments, and physical activities like sports, additional ventilation is required, as determined by an individual school's hygiene plan. These activities should take place outside whenever possible. When outdoor activity is not possible, students must remain at least two meters apart when playing music, and one meter apart when playing sports, unless like sport required physical contact. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Education,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 25, 2021, the Austrian government announced a school regulation requiring a three-week safety phase at the beginning of the academic year 2021/2022. During this phase, pupils, teachers, and administrative staff must (1) wear face coverings in hallways and common areas (not classrooms); (2) provide proof of negative coronavirus tests at least once per week, or as often as necessary to demonstrate low epidemiological risk. Teachers and administrative staff are exempt from the testing requirement if they provide proof of vaccination against COVID-19. The policy applies to the academic year 2021/2022, which began on November 1, 2021, and will end around July 9, 2022.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
